children.name: water power
children.definition: power that is obtained from water flowing from one level to a lower level: sức nước; thuỷ lực

children.name: energy
children.definition: power that is used to provide heat, operate machines etc : năng lượng
examples: The water is heated using energy from the sun.
The problem with nuclear energy is dealing with the waste.
nuclear/atomic energya report on the cost of nuclear energy
generate/produce energya power plant that generates energy from household waste
energy use30% of all our energy use is in the home.
energy needs/requirements65% of the country’s energy needs are met by imported oil.
energy productionhydro-electricity and other methods of energy production
an energy companya state-owned energy company
the energy industryregulation of the energy industry

children.name: solar energy
examples: The water pump is powered by solar energy.

children.name: wind/wave energy
examples: The windmill uses wind energy to crush grain and pump water.

children.name: renewable energy
children.definition: energy such as solar or wind energy that can be replaced naturally
examples: Switching to sources of renewable energy will reduce carbon emissions.

children.name: alternative energy
children.definition: energy from sources other than oil, coal, or nuclear energy
examples: It is the first form of public transport to be powered by alternative energy.

children.name: clean energy
children.definition: which does not cause pollution
examples: Iceland possesses sufficient quantities of clean energy sources that it does not need to rely on fossil fuels.

children.name: supply/provide energy
examples: The wind farm will provide enough energy for 100,000 homes.

children.name: store energy
examples: Batteries store the energy from the solar panels.

children.name: use energy
examples: Washing machines use a lot of energy.

children.name: conserve energy
children.definition: not waste any energy
examples: An efficient boiler will conserve energy and save you money.

children.name: energy efficiency
examples: This guide provides advice on ways of improving energy efficiency.

children.name: energy consumption
examples: We all need to reduce our energy consumption.

children.name: energy resources
examples: The world’s energy resources are being used up at an alarming rate.

children.name: an energy shortage
examples: California experienced energy shortages that in turn led to power outages.

children.name: an energy crisis
examples: Europe could soon face an energy crisis.

children.name: energy supplies
examples: We must secure the country’s future energy supplies.

children.name: an energy bill
examples: We are looking at ways of cutting our energy bill.

children.name: energy prices
examples: Energy prices are likely to rise significantly in the near future.

children.name: a source/form of energy
examples: Coal is more expensive than other sources of energy.

children.name: the demand for energy
examples: The demand for energy in developing countries will continue to grow.

children.name: fuel
children.definition: a substancewhich is used to provide heat or power, usually by being burned: nhiên liệu, chất đốt
examples: Wood, coal, oil, petrol and gas are all different kinds of fuel.
Plutonium is a fuel used to produce nuclear energy.

children.name: a fossil fuel
children.definition: a fuel such as coal or oil, produced by the gradual decaying of plants and animals
examples: nhiên liệu hóa thạchGlobal warming may be caused by burning fossil fuels.

children.name: nuclear fuel
examples: What do we do with the spent nuclear fuel?

children.name: solid fuel
children.definition: a solid substance, such as coal, that is used as a fuel
examples: nhiên liệu rắnThe number of homes using solid fuel for heating has decreased.

children.name: domestic/household fuel
children.definition: used in a house
examples: There has been a sharp rise in domestic fuel costs.

children.name: smokeless fuel
children.definition: that burns without producing smoke
examples: The government is trying to encourage the use of environmentally-friendly smokeless fuels.

children.name: unleaded fuel
children.definition: that does not contain lead
examples: Modern cars run on unleaded fuel.

children.name: a green fuel
children.definition: a fuel that harms the environment as little as possible
examples: Are green fuels, like Biodiesel, really the solution to our fuel crisis?

children.name: a clean fuel
children.definition: fuel that does not harm the environment
examples: The proposal is to cut tax on cars that run on clean fuel.

children.name: aviation fuel
children.definition: used used by planes
examples: high-octane aviation fuel

children.name: use fuel
examples: People need to learn how to use fuel more efficiently.

children.name: run on fuel
children.definition: use fuel as the source of power
examples: Will this engine run on unleaded fuel?

children.name: run out of fuel
children.definition: use all the fuel available and have none left
examples: The ship ran out of fuel and drifted helplessly.

children.name: fill up with fuel
children.definition: put fuel in a vehicle's fuel tank
examples: Before leaving, I filled up with fuel at the local petrol station.

children.name: save fuel
examples: You can save fuel by not driving too fast.

children.name: waste fuel
examples: The booklet gives helpful tips on how to avoid wasting fuel.

children.name: fuel costs/prices
examples: The increase in fuel costs is severely affecting pensioners.

children.name: a fuel bill
examples: Insulating your house will cut your fuel bill.

children.name: a fuel tank
children.definition: a container for storing fuel
examples: The fuel tank holds 14 gallons of petrol.

children.name: a fuel gauge
children.definition: an instrument for measuring fuel
examples: I noticed the fuel gauge was on empty so I pulled into the nearest gas station.

children.name: a fuel pump
children.definition: a machine that forces fuel into an engine
examples: The car's fuel pump was leaking.

children.name: fuel consumption
children.definition: amount used
examples: Fuel consumption averages 54 miles per gallon.

children.name: fuel economy/efficiency
children.definition: how well a vehicle uses fuel, without wasting any
examples: Greater engine efficiency has led to improved fuel economy.

children.name: something is running low on fuel
children.definition: it does not have much fuel left
examples: The plane was running low on fuel.

children.name: biofuel
children.definition: a fuel that is made from living things or their waste : nhiên liệu sinh học

children.name: solar
children.definition: using the energy from the sun to produce electric power : sử dụng năng lượng mặt trời
examples: a solar cell/panel
solar heating

children.name: solar panel
children.definition: a device that changes energy from the sun into electricity: tấm pin mặt trời
examples: Solar panels are used to power satellites.

children.name: nuclear
children.definition: being or using the power produced when the nucleus of an atom is divided or joined to another nucleus
examples: the nuclear industry
nuclear energy/ power
France’s reliance onnuclear energy
a nuclear power station/ a nuclear power plant
a nuclear-powered submarine

children.name: on
children.definition: used to show sth which is used fuel
examples: Does this radiorunon batteries?

children.name: run on
children.definition: sth if a machine runs on a particular type or supply of power, it uses that power to work : chạy bằn
examples: Some calculators run on solar power.

children.name: refuel
children.definition: to fill a plane or vehicle with fuel before continuing a journey :tiếp nhiên liệu
examples: The plane was refuelled in Dubai.

children.name: feed
children.definition: to put fuel on or inside sth that burns, to keep it burning : cung cấp vật liệu cho
examples: Remember to feed the fire while I'm out.

children.name: power
children.definition: to supply power to a vehicle or machine :cấp nguồn, cung cấp lực
examples: It’s powered by a Ferrari V12 engine.
Buses and trucks are usually powered by diesel engines.
In the future electricity will be used to power road vehicles.

children.name: fuel
children.definition: to supply a system with a substance which can be burnt to provide heat or power: cấpnhiên liệu
examples: Our heating system is fuelledbygas.

children.name: coal
children.definition: a hard black mineral which is dug out of the ground and burnt to produce heat or a piece of coal, especially one that is burning : than đá
examples: Put some coal on the fire.
the coal mining industry
a lump of coal
Red hot coals glowed in the grate.
How much coal wasminedhere?
a burning/red hot coal

children.name: oil
children.definition: a smooth thick liquid that is used to make machines run easily or is burned to produce heat : dầu
examples: Check the oil level in your car every week.
The heating system runs on oil.

children.name: gas
children.definition: a clear substance like air that is burned for heating or cooking : khí ga
examples: The explosion was caused by agas leakfrom the water heater.

children.name: natural gas
children.definition: gas used for cooking and heating, taken from under the earth or from under the sea
examples: The main part of natural gas is methane.

children.name: a gas cooker/oven/stove
examples: Gas cookers are more efficient than electric ones.

children.name: a gas fire
children.definition: an object that burns gas to heat a room
examples: She turned on the gas fire.

children.name: a gas cylinder
children.definition: a large container for gas
examples: One of the gas cylinders exploded.

children.name: a gas bottle
children.definition: a small container for gas
examples: The gas bottles need to be stored in a safe place.

children.name: a gas leak
children.definition: an escape of gas through a hole in something
examples: If you suspect a gas leak, do not strike a match or even turn on an electric light.

children.name: a gas supply
children.definition: a system for supplying gas to someone's house
examples: The engineers had quite a challenge to install the new gas supply.

children.name: gas reserves
children.definition: a supply of gas kept to be used when it is needed
examples: Norway has far greater gas reserves than the UK.

children.name: a gas pipeline
examples: The Chinese and Russian governments are cooperating in gas pipeline projects.

children.name: a gas bill
children.definition: a bill you have to pay for gas you have used
examples: Household gas bills have increased dramatically.

children.name: gas production
examples: The company expanded its gas production facilities.

children.name: the gas industry
examples: There are plans to nationalize the country's gas industry.

children.name: firewood
children.definition: wood used as fuel for a fire: củi
examples: We can use those old shelves as firewood.
